g.text: across economic sectors as well as
policy areas, e.g. from a trade policy perspective, in most countries,
tariff barriers are substantially lower on relatively more CO
. Available inventories of fossil fuel subsidies (in the form of direct budgetary transfers,
risk transfers, or induced transfers), covering 76 economies, indicate a rise to USD
340 billion in 2017, a 5% increase compared to 2016. Such trend is due to slowed down progress in
reducing support among OECD and G20 economies in 2017
and to a rise in fossil
turn, reduces the efficiency of public instruments and incentives aimed at redi
As a result, the demand for fossil fuels, especially in the energy production, transport and buildings
sectors, remain high, and the risk
. Political economy constraints of fossil fuel subsidy reform continue to be
a major hurdle for climate action
Financing needs are discussed in various contexts
only one being international climate politics and
finance. Also, financing needs are used as an indicator for required system changes (when compared to
current flows and asset bases) and an indicator for near
Investment needs are widely used as an indicator focusing on
initial investments required to realise new infrastructure. It compares relatively well with private sector
ents but lacks comparability and explanatory power
regarding the needs in the context of international climate cooperation where considerations on
economic costs play a more substantial role. Chapter 12 elaborates on global economic cost estimates
This indicator includes both costs and benefits of options, of which
related costs make up only one component.
here are financing needs not directly related to the realisation of p
not covered in both, investment and cost estimates. For instance, the need for building institutional
capacity facilitating to achieve social and economic goals underpinning knowledge, skills, notional and
might not be significant, but an enabling environment for future investments
would not be established without satisfying it. Moreover, comprehending financial needs for addressing
economic losses due to climate change can hardly be measured i
n terms of the indicators introduced
Understanding the magnitude of the challenge to scale
up finance in sectors and regions requires a more
comprehensive (and qualitative) assessment of the needs. For finance to become an enabler of the
, domestic and international public interventions can be needed to ensure enough supply of
finance across sectors, regions and stakeholders. The location of financing needs and vicinity to capital
(Fuchs et al. 2017; OECD 2017a; Ito and McCauley 2019)
country or regions), transaction costs and risk considerations (see also 15.2). Most of the finance is
mobilised domestically but the depth of capital markets is substantially greater in developed countries,
mobilise substantial volumes of additional funding for many developing
countries. The same applies to various stakeholders with limited connections into the financial sector.
enabling financial market frameworks, guidelines and su
infrastructure is crucial for inclusive finance for the bottom of the pyramid (BoP), especially
disadvantaged and economically marginalised segments of society.
